feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 25 at 5:27AM EDT until October 25 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...The beaches north of Cape Hatteras.
* WHEN...Through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 9 AM this morning.

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: High Wind Watch issued October 25 at 3:13AM MDT until October 28 at 3:00AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Southwest winds 35 to 45 mph with gusts up to 70 mph possible.
* WHERE...The Rocky Mountain Front and adjacent foothills and plains, and Eastern Glacier, Western Toole, and Central Pondera Counties.
* WHEN...From Sunday afternoon through late Sunday night.
* IMPACTS...High winds may move loose debris, damage property and cause isolated power outages. Travel could be difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Glacier Park Region; Northern High Plains; Eastern Glacier, Western Toole, and Central Pondera; Southern Rocky Mountain Front; Southern High Plains

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 25 at 4:31AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
The combination of recent dry weather, very dry fuels and relative humidity between 30 and 45 percent makes conditions favorable for wildfire spread today.
Use caution when handling and disposing of ignition sources.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 25 at 4:27AM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
An increased risk of fire spread will continue today. Low relative humidity of 25 to 35 percent and dry fuels will support the spread of any fires that ignite.
Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged. Be sure to properly extinguish or dispose of any potential ignition sources, including smoking materials such as cigarette butts. Refer to the New Jersey Forest Fire Service web site for information on burn restrictions.
The risk of fire spread on Saturday should be even greater, with similar relative humidity and northwest winds gusting to 20 to 30 mph.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Passaic; Eastern Passaic; Hudson; Western Bergen; Eastern Bergen; Western Essex; Eastern Essex; Western Union; Eastern Union

cap:parameter.value: ELEVATED RISK OF WILDFIRE SPREAD TODAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 25 at 6:16PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
Tropical Depression Kong-rey (23W) is located west-northwest of Rota near 15N144E and is moving northwest, away from the Marianas. However, radar and satellite data show the heaviest weather is displaced to the north and east of the center, mainly near and north of Tinian and Saipan, with some showers moving into the far northern islands such as Alamagan and Pagan. Strongest winds of 25 to 35 mph and gusts to 60 mph remain in the monsoonal flow wrapping along the eastern and northern edge of TD Kong-rey, and are mainly contained in a band of showers and heavy cloud cover that extends from Tinian up to just north of Anatahan and slopes southeast, east of the Marianas coastal waters, and towards Chuuk, into the overall monsoonal pattern associated with 98W. At Guam and Rota weather as been calmer but rain bands trailing east of TD Kong-rey are moving in this evening and tonight, potentially bringing periods of locally heavy rainfall and gust to 30 mph in these showers.
IMPACTS THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT:
-For Tinian and Saipan winds will be around 25 to 35 mph. Gust to 60 mph are expected to decrease to 45 mph after midnight tonight as the strongest gusts move northwest and way from the Marianas with TD Kong- rey. For Guam and Rota winds of 15 to 20 mph are expected over night but showers will bring gusts up to 30 mph.
-Greatest potential for heavy rain tonight remain around and north of Tinian and Saipan, extending up to Pagan. Developing rain bands east of Kong-rey will bring periods of locally heavy showers to Guam and Rota over night.
-Winds at Tinian and Saipan are expected to become breezy Saturday morning, dropping to 15 to 25 mph, while 15 to 20 mph are expected for Guam and Rota. Winds across all the Marianas are expected to become 15 to 20 mph Saturday night as the monsoonal pattern start to weaken as TD Kong-rey continues to move away. Scattered to at times numerous showers and isolated thunderstorms will continue through at least Sunday night as the Marianas remains on the edge of the monsoonal pattern and 98W as they are pulled northwest by TD Kong- rey.
-Hazardous surf and marine conditions will start to ease, but surf and sea conditions may remain choppy due to swell from TD Kong-rey and the monsoonal pattern in western Micronesia.

cap:parameter.value: TROPICAL DEPRESSION KONG-REY (23W) IS MOVING NORTHWEST STARTING TO MOVE AWAY FROM THE MARIANAS... ...HEAVY RAIN AND WINDS REMAIN DISPLACED TO THE NORTH AND EAST OF TD KONG-RAY... ...98W REMAINS DISORGANIZED SOUTHEAST OF THE MARIANAS...IN THE MONSOONAL PATTERN ACROSS EASTER YAP AND WESTERN CHUUK STATE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 25 at 5:39PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
A strong westerly monsoon pattern persists across western Micronesia. The worst conditions are found between Yap and Chuuk and areas south. Satellite data has shown numerous to widespread showers stretching from just south of Yap Proper eastward into Chuuk State west and northwest of Weno. Strong winds of 20 to 30 mph and rough seas have continued across the region well outside of the showers. Invest 99W has formed into Tropical Depression Kong-rey (23W) while invest 98W is located just southeast of Guam. As both features move northwestward, the monsoonal pattern will lift northwest. This will bring the region of showers and thunderstorms back into Palau and Yap Sunday and into early next week.
This monsoonal pattern will make inter-island travel hazardous and potentially dangerous at times so travel is discouraged through the rest of week and into the weekend. Watch out for high surf along west and north facing reefs and pay attention to surf and sea conditions.
Residents across Yap and Chuuk States should continue to monitor local weather forecasts from the National Weather Service in Guam, and for additional information from your local Weather Service Office and emergency management. Visit weather.gov/gum/PublicForecasts for the latest weather information from the National Weather Service.

cap:parameter.value: STRONG MONSOONAL PATTERN CONTINUES ACROSS EASTERN YAP AND WESTERN CHUUK STATES

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued October 25 at 5:33PM ChST until October 26 at 6:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 8 to 11 feet, and dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM ChST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...As TD Kong-rey (23W) continues to pull away from the Marianas, surf will decrease along north and east facing reefs, but may start to increase along south and especially west facing reefs.

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued October 25 at 5:29PM ChST until October 26 at 12:00AM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Southeast winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 60 mph, becoming southeast 20 to 30 mph with gust to 45 mph after midnight.
* WHERE...Saipan and Tinian
* WHEN...For the High Wind Warning, until midnight ChST tonight. For the Wind Advisory, from midnight tonight to 6 PM ChST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Strong winds and damaging gusts will blow down tarps and canopies. Power outages are possible. Travel will be difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Sustained wind up to 35 mph and gusts to 60 mph within showers, especially in the higher terrain, will move moving through Saipan and Tinian as the strongest winds are displaced north of TD Kong-Rey. As Kong-Rey pulls northwest of the Marianas the severity of gusts will subside, allowing the High Wind Warning to be replaced by a Wind Advisory after midnight.

* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 7 to 9 ft.
* WHERE...West and north facing reefs of Yap.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM ChST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM CHST MONDAY

entry.title: Dense Fog Advisory issued October 24 at 10:58PM PDT until October 25 at 9:00AM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Visibility one quarter mile or less in dense fog.
* WHERE...All coastal areas in Los Angeles, Ventura, and southern Santa Barbara Counties.
* WHEN...Until 9 AM PDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Low visibility could make driving conditions hazardous.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Near zero visibility is possible on some roadways, including the Pacific Coast Highway, Highway 101 in Ventura and Santa Barbara Counties, and the 10, 405, 605, and 710 freeways in Los Angeles County.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Santa Barbara County Southwestern Coast; Santa Barbara County Southeastern Coast; Ventura County Beaches; Ventura County Inland Coast; Malibu Coast; Los Angeles County Beaches; Los Angeles County Inland Coast including Downtown Los Angeles

cap:parameter.value: DENSE FOG ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 AM PDT FRIDAY

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued October 24 at 9:27PM AKDT until October 26 at 7:00AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Southeast winds 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 60 mph expected.
* WHERE...Prince of Wales Island, especially western Prince of Wales Island.
* WHEN...From 7 PM Friday to 7 AM AKDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...High winds will blow around unsecured objects and may damage property and cause power outages. Travel will be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Strongest wind gusts will be along the west, especially southwest, portion of Prince of Wales Island. The east side of the island can still expect strong wind gusts, but wind gust speeds are more likely to be around 40 to 50 mph.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH WIND WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 7 PM FRIDAY TO 7 AM AKDT SATURDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 24 at 7:31PM AKDT until October 25 at 7:00AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blowing snow. Visibility will be reduced to one half mile or less at times. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Eastern Beaufort Sea Coast.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM AKDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM AKDT FRIDAY

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued October 24 at 3:35PM HST until October 26 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR ALL EAST FACING SHORES THROUGH SATURDAY...
.A moderate to large, medium period NNE (010-030 degrees) swell will produce advisory level surf along east-facing shores through Saturday. Swell and subsequent surf will peak Friday afternoon then slowly decline through the weekend.
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 7 to 10 feet increasing to 9 to 12 feet on Friday.
* WHERE...East facing shores of Kauai, Oahu, Maui, Molokai, and Big Island.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Moderate. Strong breaking waves and strong currents will make swimming dangerous.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Olomana; Maui Windward West; Kauai East; Koolau Windward; Molokai Southeast; Windward Haleakala; Big Island East; Big Island North

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM HST SATURDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 24 at 9:04PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.
.The Saint Johns River at Astor remains in Major Flood Stage but is forecast to continue a gradual decline through the weekend into next week, falling into Moderate flood. Residents and interests along the Saint Johns River should be prepared for prolonged flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Major flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Friday morning at 1100 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Major flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 4.0 feet, Major flooding occurs with water entering many structures on canals and along the river. Long duration flooding will occur, with levels taking weeks to months to return below flood stage. Water rescues will be necessary. River Road becomes inaccessible, with 1 to 2 feet water depth in numerous homes on Wildhog, Possum, Bonnet and Snail roads. Roads along Blue Creek are inaccessible with major flooding of homes on Otter, Branch and Chestnut roads. Camp South Moon Road and Juno Trail are inaccessible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 4.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Thursday was 4.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 4.0 feet. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 24 at 9:02PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Deland affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.
.The river level at Deland remains right at Major Flood Stage, 5.3 feet, but is forecast to gradually fall into Moderate flood by around early Friday afternoon and continue through Moderate flood over the next 5 days. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River at Deland should be prepared for continued flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Deland...Major flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Friday morning at 1100 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Deland.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 5.3 feet, Major flooding occurs to many structures and marinas along the river and in the Hontoon Island area.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 5.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 3.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Thursday was 5.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 5.3 feet just after midnight tonight. - Flood stage is 4.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 24 at 8:58PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Sanford affecting Seminole County.
.The river at Sanford is forecast to continue a slow decline through Minor Flood Stage over the next 5 days. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River at Sanford should be prepared for prolonged minor flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Sanford...Minor flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Friday morning at 1100 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Sanford.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Water begins to move over sea wall around Lake Monroe and rises into grassy areas around the sea wall. Water begins to encroach on Seminole Boulevard.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 6.9 feet. - Bankfull stage is 4.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Thursday was 7.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 6.9 feet. - Flood stage is 5.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Above Lake Harney affecting Seminole County.
.The river at Geneva near Lake Harney is forecast to continue a gradual decline through Moderate Flood Stage over the next 5 days. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River near Lake Harney should stay up to date on the forecast this week and prepare for prolonged flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Above Lake Harney...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Friday morning at 1100 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Above Lake Harney.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.5 feet, Water begins to move into homes in low lying areas along the river. Flooding around the Black Hammock area near Lake Jesup.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 9.5 feet. - Bankfull stage is 6.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Thursday was 9.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 9.5 feet. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 24 at 7:52PM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
An increased risk of fire spread will continue into Friday. Low relative humidity of 25 to 35 percent and dry fuels will support the spread of any fires that ignite, which could become difficult to control.
Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged. Be sure to properly extinguish or dispose of any potential ignition sources, including smoking materials such as cigarette butts. Refer to the New Jersey Forest Fire Service web site for information on burn restrictions.
The risk of fire spread on Saturday should be even greater, with similar relative humidity and northwest winds gusting to 20 to 30 mph.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Passaic; Eastern Passaic; Hudson; Western Bergen; Eastern Bergen; Western Essex; Eastern Essex; Western Union; Eastern Union

cap:parameter.value: INCREASED RISK OF FIRE SPREAD ON FRIDAY FOR NORTHEAST NEW JERSEY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 24 at 7:52PM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
The combination of recent dry weather, very dry fuels and relative humidity between 30 and 40 percent will make conditions once again favorable for wildfire spread on Friday. Fires that start have the potential to spread quickly and may become difficult to contain.
Use caution when handling and disposing of ignition sources.
The risk of wildfire spread on Saturday should be even greater, with similar relative humidity and northwest winds gusting to 20 to 25 mph.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Fairfield; Northern New Haven; Northern Middlesex; Northern New London; Southern Fairfield; Southern New Haven; Southern Middlesex; Southern New London

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 24 at 5:58PM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
There continues to be an increased risk of fire spread into Friday. Relative humidity are expected to drop into the 25 to 35 percent range across much of the area. These low relative humidity values are combined with west winds around 10 to 15 mph and temperatures in the low to mid 60s, and abundant sunshine. These conditions will support the spread of any fires that ignite, which could quickly become difficult to control.
Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged. Be sure to properly extinguish or dispose of any potential ignition sources, including smoking materials such as cigarette butts. Refer to your state's forest fire management agency for more information on burn restrictions in your local area.
Relative humidity values will be similar on Saturday, with stronger wind gusts. Burn restrictions may still be in place given the very dry conditions and lack of any recent rainfall.
entry.cap:areaDesc: New Castle; Kent; Inland Sussex; Delaware Beaches; Kent; Queen Anne's; Talbot; Caroline; Sussex; Warren; Morris; Hunterdon; Somerset; Middlesex; Western Monmouth; Eastern Monmouth; Mercer; Salem; Gloucester; Camden; Northwestern Burlington; Ocean; Cumberland; Atlantic; Cape May; Atlantic Coastal Cape May; Coastal Atlantic; Coastal Ocean; Southeastern Burlington; Carbon; Monroe; Berks; Lehigh; Northampton; Delaware; Philadelphia; Western Chester; Eastern Chester; Western Montgomery; Eastern Montgomery; Upper Bucks; Lower Bucks
